review.title: A Hybrid LP-RPG Heuristic for Modelling Numeric Resource Flows in Planning
review.abstract: Although the use of metric fluents is fundamental to many practical planning problems, the study of heuristics to support fully automated planners working with these fluents remains relatively unexplored. The most widely used heuristic is the relaxation of metric fluents into interval-valued variables --- an idea first proposed a decade ago. Other heuristics depend on domain encodings that supply additional information about fluents, such as capacity constraints or other resource-related annotations. A particular challenge to these approaches is in handling interactions between metric fluents that represent exchange, such as the transformation of quantities of raw materials into quantities of processed goods, or trading of money for materials. The usual relaxation of metric fluents is often very poor in these situations, since it does not recognise that resources, once spent, are no longer available to be spent again. We present a heuristic for numeric planning problems building on the propositional relaxed planning graph, but using a mathematical program for numeric reasoning. We define a class of producer--consumer planning problems and demonstrate how the numeric constraints in these can be modelled in a mixed integer program (MIP). This MIP is then combined with a metric Relaxed Planning Graph (RPG) heuristic to produce an integrated hybrid heuristic. The MIP tracks resource use more accurately than the usual relaxation, but relaxes the ordering of actions, while the RPG captures the causal propositional aspects of the problem. We discuss how these two components interact to produce a single unified heuristic and go on to explore how further numeric features of planning problems can be integrated into the MIP. We show that encoding a limited subset of the propositional problem to augment the MIP can yield more accurate guidance, partly by exploiting structure such as propositional landmarks and propositional resources. Our results show that the use of this heuristic enhances scalability on problems where numeric resource interaction is key in finding a solution.

sections.heading: 3.2 Problems with the Metric RPG Heuristic
sections.text: Although metric role-playing is a powerful tool to support planning with metric fluids, there are some common situations in planning problems where heuristics give very flawed guidance. These issues include resource persistence and cyclical resource transfer. We discuss how each of these phenomena can lead to misleading heuristic guidance, as the loosened plan length poorly approximates the actual solution length and is distorted by helpful action distortions.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Resource Persistence
sections.text: The ability to reuse the resource may indicate that a much shorter plan is available than is the case in reality. Although this problem occurs for both propositional and metric flows, the fact that metric flows often code resources that need to be carefully managed means that the problem is more acute in areas with metric flows. For example, in a settler domain state where 2 units of each resource have been produced and no ship is needed (either as a destination or as a means to travel to an otherwise inaccessible place), no relaxed plan will require the production of additional resources (see Table 1). An approach to approximating the number of missing resource productions was introduced in planner Sapa (Do & Kambhampati, 2001).

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Cyclical Resource Transfer
sections.text: The phenomenon of Cyclical Resource Transfer (CRT) is a consequence of the coding of actions that move resources, combined with the loosening of negative effects. To encode the movement of a resource, it is removed from one place and added to another. Distance is encoded as reduction and this is eased when building the metric role play. As a result, moving resources at the destination seems to generate new resources, making movement a falsely attractive alternative to production. Consider a state where 1 unit of wood and a cart are in one place, P1, and the goal is to have 2 units of wood on P1. Of course, the solution plan must include the production of more wood. However, a valid, relaxed plan solution found heuristically with the help of the metric role play is: 0: (Load v1 p1 wood) 1: (Discharge v1 p1 wood).

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Helpful Action Distortion
sections.text: The problems of resource scarcity and CRT have an important consequence for the EHC search. Not only do they lead to relaxed plans with misleadingly short lengths, but the relaxed plans typically contain too few production actions and useless transfer actions. In this situation, production actions often do not appear in the helpful action plans and are therefore not included in the EHC search, even in states where they could be conveniently applied. We call this problem a helpful distortion of action. To illustrate how this arises, again in relation to the settler domain, we consider a state in which there is a timber unit at Site A, and the goal is to have a timber unit at Site B. A relaxed plan can use the timber to build a wagon and then load the same timber onto the wagon to transport it. Therefore, the planner will not consider producing more timber.

sections.heading: 7. Extending the Scope of Numeric Reasoning in the LP
sections.text: In Section 4, we discussed an LP coding that captures the producer-consumer behavior of actions as used in the first version of LPRPG (Coles et al., 2008).In this section, we discuss how this coding can be improved by using additional numerical information that represents the structure of the planning problem to improve the guidance that the resulting heuristics can provide to the planner. We address two key questions here: ensuring that conjunctions can be met via numerical targets, and taking into account the problem of fragmented actions in the LP.

sections.heading: 7.1 Checking Numeric Goals alongside Propositional Goals
sections.text: In Section 6.1, we pointed out that we can restrict the LP so that it finds measures to achieve statement goals. We can expand this further to include numerical targets, N? by adding each numerical target directly to the LP as a constraint. As with statement targets, this has clear advantages in terms of resource persistence (Section 3.2.1) by insisting that all targets are achievable at the same time, rather than just individually achievable. However, it also increases the meaningfulness of the numerical targets that we are able to handle for anything that can be expressed in linear normal form (LNF) - any LNF formula can be added to the LP as a constraint.

sections.heading: 7.2 Catalytic Resources
sections.text: These are variables that represent resources that either need to be generated or purchased by reactions, but once they are present, other reactions are possible, or allow them to occur more quickly. For these catalytic reactions, the resource needs to be present, but it is not consumed, although other non-catalytic reactions might consume the resource. Another example that could be considered is the construction of a unit in a plant to support some processes, the unit needs to be there to support the process, but once constructed to enable other actions without destroying the resource.

metadata.abstractText: Although the use of metric fluents is fundamental to many practical planning problems, the study of heuristics to support fully automated planners working with these fluents remains relatively unexplored. The most widely used heuristic is the relaxation of metric fluents into interval-valued variables — an idea first proposed a decade ago. Other heuristics depend on domain encodings that supply additional information about fluents, such as capacity constraints or other resource-related annotations. A particular challenge to these approaches is in handling interactions between metric fluents that represent exchange, such as the transformation of quantities of raw materials into quantities of processed goods, or trading of money for materials. The usual relaxation of metric fluents is often very poor in these situations, since it does not recognise that resources, once spent, are no longer available to be spent again. We present a heuristic for numeric planning problems building on the propositional relaxed planning graph, but using a mathematical program for numeric reasoning. We define a class of producer–consumer planning problems and demonstrate how the numeric constraints in these can be modelled in a mixed integer program (MIP). This MIP is then combined with a metric Relaxed Planning Graph (RPG) heuristic to produce an integrated hybrid heuristic. The MIP tracks resource use more accurately than the usual relaxation, but relaxes the ordering of actions, while the RPG captures the causal propositional aspects of the problem. We discuss how these two components interact to produce a single unified heuristic and go on to explore how further numeric features of planning problems can be integrated into the MIP. We show that encoding a limited subset of the propositional problem to augment the MIP can yield more accurate guidance, partly by exploiting structure such as propositional landmarks and propositional resources. Our results show that the use of this heuristic enhances scalability on problems where numeric resource interaction is key in finding a solution.
